headline: Stage-specific upregulation during early intracellular development in Cryptosporidium parvum
one_paragraph_summary: This Cryptosporidium parvum gene exhibits stage-specific expression patterns with peak activity during early intracellular development. Expression is dramatically upregulated in intracellular stages (15.7-66.63 TPM) compared to oocysts (0.37 TPM), representing a ~42-fold increase. The gene shows temporal regulation with highest expression at 12-24 hours post-infection, followed by decline at later time points. Expression remains consistently low or undetectable in sporozoites and oocysts across multiple studies. This expression pattern suggests the gene plays a critical role in early infection establishment and parasite development within host cells, potentially involved in metabolic processes or host cell manipulation during the initial stages of parasitic life cycle progression.

topics.headline: Dramatic upregulation in intracellular stages versus dormant oocysts
topics.one_sentence_summary: Gene expression increases ~42-fold from oocysts (0.37 TPM) to intracellular stages (15.7-66.63 TPM), demonstrating clear stage-specific activation during parasitic development.

topics.headline: Temporal expression peaks at 12-24 hours post-infection
topics.one_sentence_summary: Expression reaches maximum levels during early infection (12-24 hours post-infection) before declining sharply, indicating involvement in early developmental processes.

topics.headline: Complex transcriptional regulation with antisense expression in vitro
topics.one_sentence_summary: Gene shows moderate expression in host tissue infections but exhibits prominent antisense transcription in HCT-8 cell culture, suggesting complex regulatory mechanisms.
